text: I will offer unto thee burnt sacrifices of fatlings, with the incense of rams; I will offer bullocks with goats. Selah.
text_kjv: I will offer unto thee burnt sacrifices of fatlings, with the incense of rams; I will offer bullocks with goats. Selah.
text_niv: I will sacrifice fat animals to youand an offering of rams;I will offer bulls and goats. Selah
text_esv: I will offer to you burnt offerings of fattened animals, with the smoke of the sacrifice of rams; I will make an offering of bulls and goats. Selah
text_nlt: That is why I am sacrificing burnt offerings to you —the best of my rams as a pleasing aroma,and a sacrifice of bulls and male goats. Interlude
text_msg: The choicest cuts of meatfor the sacrificial meal;Even the fragranceof roasted lamb is like a meal!Or make it an oxgarnished with goat meat!
text_nasb: I shall offer to You burnt offerings of fat beasts, With the smoke of rams; I shall make [an offering of] bulls with male goats. Selah.
context: Psalm 66 is a song of praise and thanksgiving to God for his mighty acts of deliverance and provision. Verses 13-15 focus on the psalmist's promised sacrificial offerings. The Old Testament sacrificial system was central to Israelite worship, serving as a means of atonement, thanksgiving, fellowship, and dedication. Burnt offerings were particularly significant, involving the complete burning of an animal on the altar as a symbol of complete devotion to God. The 'fatlings' mentioned refer to choice, well-fed animals, signifying the best quality offerings. 'Incense of rams' likely refers to the aroma produced by burning the fat and select parts of rams, which was pleasing to God. Bullocks (young bulls) and goats were also common sacrificial animals, each representing varying degrees of atonement and thanksgiving. The burnt offering required the offerer to place their hand on the animal's head, confessing sins and symbolically transferring them to the animal before it was slaughtered. Priests then prepared the sacrifice and burned it on the altar. The meticulous process emphasized the holiness of God and the need for atonement for sin. 'Selah' is a musical notation, likely indicating a pause for reflection or a musical interlude, emphasizing the importance of the preceding words.
meaning: Theologically, Psalm 66:15 highlights the importance of sincere worship and gratitude to God. The psalmist’s intention to offer choice sacrifices reflects a deep commitment to honoring God with the very best. The phrase 'burnt sacrifices of fatlings' symbolizes a complete and unreserved dedication to God's will. The offering of different animals—rams, bullocks, and goats—suggests a comprehensive approach to worship, encompassing various aspects of atonement, thanksgiving, and fellowship. The burning of incense was symbolic of prayers ascending to God, representing a spiritual offering alongside the physical sacrifice. The inclusion of 'Selah' invites the reader to pause and contemplate the significance of these offerings, urging reflection on the depth of gratitude and commitment expressed in the psalm. While Christians today do not practice animal sacrifices (Hebrews 10:1-18), the underlying principle of offering our best to God remains relevant. Our 'sacrifices' now involve dedicating our time, talents, resources, and affections to Him, mirroring the psalmist's heartfelt devotion. The verse underscores that true worship is not merely outward ritual, but an inward disposition of humility, gratitude, and unwavering commitment to God.
application: In modern application, Psalm 66:15 challenges us to examine our own worship and commitment to God. While we are not called to offer animal sacrifices, the spirit of the verse calls us to offer our best in every area of our lives. This can manifest in several ways. Firstly, it means giving our time and attention to God through prayer, Bible study, and fellowship with other believers. Just as the psalmist planned to offer specific sacrifices, we should intentionally carve out time for spiritual disciplines. Secondly, it means using our talents and abilities to serve God and others. Are we using our gifts to further God's kingdom or are we hoarding them for our own benefit? Thirdly, it means giving generously of our financial resources. Just as the psalmist offered 'fatlings,' the best of his livestock, we should be willing to give sacrificially to support God's work. Fourthly, it means offering a 'sacrifice of praise' (Hebrews 13:15). Even when life is difficult, we can choose to praise God for his faithfulness and goodness. This verse reminds us that worship is not just a Sunday morning activity, but a lifestyle of devotion and service. Furthermore, the inclusion of 'Selah' invites us to pause and reflect on the depth of our commitment. Are we truly offering our best to God, or are we settling for mediocrity? The example of the psalmist motivates us to cultivate a heart of gratitude and to express our love for God in tangible ways.
prayer: Heavenly Father, I thank you for your immeasurable grace and love. I recognize that you have given me everything I have, and I desire to offer you my best. Forgive me for the times I have settled for less, offering you only leftovers of my time, talents, and resources. Help me to cultivate a heart of genuine gratitude and to express my love for you in practical ways. Empower me to use my gifts to serve you and others. May my life be a living sacrifice, holy and pleasing to you. I ask for your guidance and strength to live a life of unwavering devotion, reflecting your love and grace in all that I do. Help me to pause and reflect on your goodness, just as 'Selah' invites us to do. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: Animal sacrifices were a central part of Old Testament worship, serving as a means of atonement for sin, thanksgiving, and establishing a covenant relationship with God. They symbolized the cost of sin and God's provision for forgiveness.

faqs.answer: While Christians don't practice animal sacrifice, the principle of offering our best to God remains. We offer our time, talents, resources, and praise as spiritual sacrifices in gratitude for His grace.
